text: <https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/637571|https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/637571>

attachments.fallback: Petitions - UK Government and Parliament: Petition: Don’t allow affordability checks for sports betting
attachments.text: The Government should ban bookmakers from conducting affordability checks on bettors. Bettors shouldn’t have to experience intrusive checks covering aspects of their finances. The Government should also abandon its proposals for frictionless checks that they’ve included in the recent white paper.
attachments.title: Petition: Don’t allow affordability checks for sports betting

elements.text: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/637571

elements.text: The title and description really doesn’t help the cause

text: Morally no, but I did just have a complete fuck up with this, and got suspended despite having never net deposited more than £100

text: A White Paper is only a proposal, probably best to wait and petition the conclusion of the review by the HoL.  I can't imagine much of it will go through in its present form.

elements.text: A White Paper is only a proposal, probably best to wait and petition the conclusion of the review by the HoL.  I can't imagine much of it will go through in its present form.

text: For professional gamblers does this even matter? Let's say for aggressive tax planning reasons a bettor with a consistent winning / net + account value does not collect any salary or regular income in the UK, what checks, if any happen?

elements.text: For professional gamblers does this even matter? Let's say for aggressive tax planning reasons a bettor with a consistent winning / net + account value does not collect any salary or regular income in the UK, what checks, if any happen?

text: It's not a big issue for pros who can never deposit (the trigger for a check) the concern is it being a deterrent to the casual losers we all depend on.

elements.text: It's not a big issue for pros who can never deposit (the trigger for a check) the concern is it being a deterrent to the casual losers we all depend on.

text: Perhaps there should be deterrents for casual losers...

elements.text: Perhaps there should be deterrents for casual losers...

text: Perhaps it's none of anyone's business if a person chooses to lose money betting. People must stop blaming governments/society and instead focus on the inability to control their emotions.

elements.text: Perhaps it's none of anyone's business if a person chooses to lose money betting. People must stop blaming governments/society and instead focus on the inability to control their emotions.

text: From an individual perspective yes, that makes complete sense. From a societal perspective it's impossible to ignore that policies shape behavior. That being said, I'm not a fan of invasive checks like these. But find it odd that many in this slack take it as a forgone conclusion that such checks are bad without posing arguments for or against

elements.text: From an individual perspective yes, that makes complete sense. From a societal perspective it's impossible to ignore that policies shape behavior. That being said, I'm not a fan of invasive checks like these. But find it odd that many in this slack take it as a forgone conclusion that such checks are bad without posing arguments for or against

text: They can't, humans are very fallible creatures and dopamine hits from gambling are intense. Having basic safety checks (similar to politely asking a visibly over drunk patron from drinking more at a pub) are reasonable social norms

elements.text: They can't, humans are very fallible creatures and dopamine hits from gambling are intense. Having basic safety checks (similar to politely asking a visibly over drunk patron from drinking more at a pub) are reasonable social norms

text: The nanny state is here to stay <@USWDY5P7G>.  Seat belts, helmets, drugs (unless it's called alcohol) etc etc.  Libertarianism vs social responsibility isn't an argument that takes 128 characters.

elements.text: The nanny state is here to stay
